data.title: Chapter 4 Turning Back the Sun in: Manipulating the Sun
data.meta_description: Abstract This article examines a sundial by the Augsburg instrument maker, Christoph Schissler (c. 1531–1608) that could re-create the biblical miracle of the Dial of Ahaz by making the sun’s shadow go backwards in time. It studies the instrument’s status and function through the lens of the “Kunststück,” the term Schissler used to describe his creation, and which is defined here as denoting a specific class of artwork, characterised by a high degree of technical, conceptual and thematic ingenuity. Discussing the dial within the wider contexts of Schissler’s other precision instruments and the dial’s own reception and afterlife, it is argued that the mode of “Kunststück” offered Schissler, the self-styled “geometricus artifex,” a means to demonstrate the principles of light refraction; and that, by enacting a biblical miracle, the dial could also provoke questions of theology, astronomy and natural philosophy among mathematically and intellectually sophisticated viewers, whether in the context of a Kunstkammer, an instrument collection, or in the possession of an unorthodox Copernican astronomer.
data.text:
Abstract

This article examines a sundial by the Augsburg instrument maker, Christoph Schissler (c. 1531–1608) that could re-create the biblical miracle of the Dial of Ahaz by making the sun’s shadow go backwards in time. It studies the instrument’s status and function through the lens of the “Kunststück,” the term Schissler used to describe his creation, and which is defined here as denoting a specific class of artwork, characterised by a high degree of technical, conceptual and thematic ingenuity. Discussing the dial within the wider contexts of Schissler’s other precision instruments and the dial’s own reception and afterlife, it is argued that the mode of “Kunststück” offered Schissler, the self-styled “geometricus artifex,” a means to demonstrate the principles of light refraction; and that, by enacting a biblical miracle, the dial could also provoke questions of theology, astronomy and natural philosophy among mathematically and intellectually sophisticated viewers, whether in the context of a Kunstkammer, an instrument collection, or in the possession of an unorthodox Copernican astronomer.
